Thanks Jim........ reading further Graham discusses a couple of early
Akasaka guards. Here he also mentions that the surface is treated in a
particular fashion with very tiny and precise 'dots' that give the
akasaka guards this kind of matt gloss sheen, pretty hard to describe
but you can't miss it when you hold one. I have had the privelidge of
handling a couple the last year, but I never noticed this surface
'treatment'. 
 
Do you know anything about that? 
 
Regards, Matthew.

Matt,
I think that Graham is talking about putting the final texture on the
guard.  The forging and shaping of the plate would be done with a normal
hammer.  Some iron guards are indeed finished with an array of tiny pock
marks like he describes.  It's more likely that this was done with a
small punch that was struck with a hammer rather than directly with a
pin-headed hammer.  It'd be a lot easier to place and control the punch,
and quicker to make and maintain the tool.  But, I wasn't there to see
it done.

Most Ko-Katchushi don't show this, BTW.  If they ever had it the traces
have rusted away.  It's easier to find on some later work.
Jim


  Gang I am reading Graham Gemmells book 'Tosogu, treasure of the
samurai'
  where he discusses an early - mid Muromachi ko-katchushi tsuba and
  mentions that a hammer nearly the size of a pin head was used to work
  (and fold?) the steel, and thus create the textures in the iron that
  make these things so pleasing to look at. I have some real trouble
  imagining this being done. I presume he is talking about a hammer a
bit
  like an ice-pick with a very small surface that actually strikes the
  metal? Why not just use a big one like the sword smith?

  - Matt
